Hey, Destin, frustum isn't exactly an old word in the sense of being archaic. We use it in computer graphics to describe the volume of space viewed by a virtual camera. A lot of the calculations that your graphics card does relate to stretching that space to be rectilinear and then flattening it into a 2D plane.

Yes frustums are in play but I don't think the clear dot has anything to do with them.
Based on what I know about "bullet resistant" "glasses" they aren't actually one solid piece of material but rather a lamination of acrylic and polycarbonate with an optically clear binder.

The reason why that little dot is see through is because the impact energy was great enough to completely pulverize the acrylic face leaving nothing but the polycarbonate backing layer.

If you shot pure acrylic the plate would completely shatter and the bullet would go through.
If you shot pure polycarbonate it would punch a clean hole and the bullet would go straight through.
Only when used in conjunction with one another does the plate begin to develop "bullet resistant" properties.

The acrylic face plate shatters on impact; this absorbs and deflects kinetic energy and Increases the surface area of the bullet (mushrooming it), essentially spreading the impact force over a greater area.
This impact force is then delivered onto the polycarbonate which acts as a "blanket" to capture the bullet and "glass" shrapnel.

I can kind of validate my theory with video footage from 2:48.
The visible "murkiness" you see is caused by the different materials flexing different amounts and the binding agent letting go. I use the term "murkiness" for lack of a better word; can you see how cloudy it is?
Now take note of the stress fractures (cracks) and compare them to the "murkiness"; notice they have nothing to do with one another. The "cracks" extend multiple different directions and in some instances far beyond the "murkiness".
These "cracks" you are seeing are caused by the acrylic separating from itself whereas the "murkiness" is caused by the separation of the rigid acrylic, from the the flexible polycarbonate. More specifically its actually the glue loosing its bond and deforming, this causes refractions and makes it loose its optical transparency.
Its the difference between "cracking" in the Xy, Xz and Yz axis. (This of course changes based on your point of view and orientation of the plate but if you read to this point I think you get what I'm saying.)

How else could I explain it?... Everyone knows what a mach cone looks like right? Well imagine the mach cone is sand (from crushed acrylic); The bullet is going to transmit its energy into the sand surrounding it, dragging it along as it plows its way into the polycarbonate (essentially fluid dynamics). Also remember that the lead bullet is physically deforming, mushrooming; pancaking if you would. All of this. combined with drag is enough to slow it down to a point where the polycarbonate can flex and act as a sort of catchers mitt. It literally bends and warps to contain the remaining energy. Its awesome.

Its the difference between 467 joules of being concentrated on a single point at the tip of the bullet versus spread out over say a nickel-quarter sized area (life and death). This stuff is sort of like tank armour except tanks use ceramic and steel which leaves them vulnerable to HESH rounds (High impact squash head) (basically it turns the tanks armour into deadly shrapnel in the form of spall) (not to be confused with spatter). Hopefully some or most of you know what I'm talking about cause I'm getting tired of writing and am way off topic now but it does lead me to ask the question: why are the inside of tanks not lined with Kevlar; or are they?

To see the perfect pressure cone,
gather 3 to 4 countertop cutouts for a sink, stack them tightly together standing up.

Using police loads for 357, at about 50 to 75 feet, fire a round and see the results at each panel.

The Front panel will have entry hole, and the rear sheet will have a 3 - 4"
cone hole exiting.

Particle board is the perfect median with only high pressure glue and wood chips.
If panels still have Formica on them,
that's fine.

Have fun.

I know I'm super late to the party, but I saw something that my initial explanation doesn't feel like it would work.
At 5:58-6:13 or so, the 50 cal flies through the acrylic, leaves its stress cone, flies on, and then the acrylic shatters into pieces. If you watch closely, the bullet itself leaves a hole with cracks protruding out of it, but after the bullet is already clear through and long gone (in terms of the slo-mo video), then the acrylic breaks apart further into the big chunks that fall to the ground. Why?

I initially thought it could have been that the cracks had momentum, but seeing as how they stop and then start again, that doesn't make sense at all. Then I thought maybe it would be the wind. I don't know for sure, but I don't see how a 50 caliber bullet wouldn't go super sonic, so maybe due to the nature of super sonic rounds the acrylic breaks the rest of the way from the force of the air wave catching up to the bullet and the cracks that the bullet left in the acrylic weakened it enough that that wind was enough to break it the rest of the way. It makes sense to me, but idk if the numbers would actually check out.

I'll be honest, i don't even know if 50 caliber rounds are super sonic at all. This is 100% hypothesis, so I could be completely wrong in every way, but if anyone knows the answer please let me know, I'm curious.

This is actually the same principle that are being used in TBM's and other non-explosive mining methods where you apply force on a point and it breaks up on the sides. It has to do with the principal stress directions. If the difference between sigma 1 and sigma 3 is sufficient you get cracks in sigma 3 directions. This is also the same effect you sometimes can see on the side in tunnels (if done poorly).

What is so cool about that last 50cal shot is you can see the bullet fully penetrate the glass then a few frames of no more fracturing then the glass completely self destructs. ...
So what's happening?
The impact pressure wave causes the primary localised fracturing ... But then that wave continues through the material to the material boundary and is reflected at the boundary ... Those waves upon return to the center interfere with attendant amplitude additions and subtractions ... in an already pre fractured medium the glass then self destructs explosively...

Regarding fracture mechanics - The force of the impact is a function of time and distance. So the acrylic is slowing down the 9mm over the space of maybe 2 or 3 mm as it compresses the acrylic. Right? Material fracturing absorbs some of the energy. What isn't absorbed goes into ricochet energy.
I thought it was interesting that the .50 cal cleared the plate and it was slightly later that the plate split. I'm guessing the force for the split came from thermal expansion. As the round went through it may have heated a thin layer to the point of softening it. But as the heat spread maybe it caused sub-softening temperatures in a larger amount of material, thus causing the biggest cracks to spread. It's a shame you don't have a thermal camera with similarly fast frame rates so you could confirm or disprove this hypothesis .

I believe the 9mm center phenomenon is being caused by the very center of impact being perfectly in line with the stress. As the plexiglass rebounds, the area around the nose fractures and shoots out, but the center still has the mass of the bullet to push back. This keeps that part from blowing back as well. The center stays intact because materials fail at the point the shear stress (or strain energy) is the highest and not necessarily where normal stresses are the highest (Force/Area). So the frustum surface just defines where these shear stresses are the highest and therefore where the material is likely to fail.

The center portion stays intact -- even under extremely high loading -- due to the fact that it is in nearly hydrostatic compression. This is where the material is being compressed evenly from all sides (by the bullet and the supporting material around it), resulting in a near zero shear stress even though normal stresses are substantial. -- An illustration of this would be to fill a cup with sand and press down. In this case the grains of sand are analogous to the atoms that make up the material. You can see there are no forces pulling the grains apart, and in fact they are all being pushed more tightly together. Alternative theory: The front tip of the bullet compresses the material in the pressure cone and physically enters the sheet. At this point, the front stops. The rear of the bullet keeps moving causing the bullet to undergo deformation. It quickly expands sideways since it cannot travel forwards. Since the bullet is partially lodged into the material, it blows material perpendicular to impact in a reverse conical shape.

Hey, 3D programmer guy here. We use the word "frustum" all the time in our field. You see, in computer graphics, you have limited resources and memory, etc, so when you take a virtual "camera", you don't render it's field of view from the camera to infinity. You take that "cone" of vision (that is actually rectangular because we project the screen through it) and you intersect two "clip" planes that are orthogonal with the view vector, and you only consider what exist between theses two planes, and the lateral edges of the frustum.

We call that Frustrum Culling.

One of my favorate parts of watching a gun firing in slow motion is that you can see the powder burning out of the front of the barrel. Contrary to popular belief the gunpowder in a gun doesn't explode it burns and pushes the bullet out of the gun it's really only the primer that explodes. That is why many guns get better velocity out of longer barrels and not just better accuracy. That is true until all the powder burns and the friction starts to slow down the bullet. This is also why you don't get anywhere near the velocity printed on the box when shooting .22LR out of a pocket pistol where the .25ACP is designed to be shot out of shorter barrels the .22LR is designed for rifles.

Based on my experience breaking rock with explosives (and degree in mining engineering) I suspect that the spalling seen from the 9mm impact is actually caused by the reflection of the impact shockwave off of the back face of the panel.  The pressure cone under the nose of the bullet is still in compression, but that reflected wave is putting the material outside the cone into tension, leading to the conchoidal fractures seen in the spalling.

The way I think about the pressure cone is that when the cross section area get bigger, the bullet is breaking more bond per second, which means that the resistance force is getting bigger. In the pistol case this force quickly put a stop to the bullet, but in the .50 case, the bullet kept moving, so its more destructive to the back side of the glass.

Bulletproof materials are specifically developed in order to have a pressure cone as close to 90 degrees as possible, spread the force outwards and never allowing the pressure to reach the back of the material. Also you have to consider heat generated by the pressure at the point of impact turning the surface plastic (plastic the material property, not the material type) which will allow it to maintain that clear and clean finish after it cools once the projectile has dropped away.

This frustum theory explains why the exit wound is generally larger than the entry wound

Regarding the lack of damage at the point of initial contact 2:50. I think there is more going on here. During contact, the point of maximum stress actually occurs below the surface, this partially explains the lack of damage. However we need to think more about the types of stress. Where the bullet first contact the major stress will be compression (not likely to cause fracture), surrounding this there is an area governed by shear stresses (Mescall zone, likely to cause fracture), further below this is a zone of tensile stress. I assume there will also be more shearing stresses at the edge of the bullet, compared to the center.

For a source check out: Shockey, D., J. Simons, and D. Curran. 2010. The damage mechanism route to better armor materials. International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology 7(5): 566-573.

Please explain because I’m super interested.
I get how the energy travels through the material in a pressure cone, which is why some materials can stop certain kinds of bullets, because of the pressure cone angle and strss=force/area. What I don’t get is why would the top face of the frustum (the point of impact) be clear while the rest of the cone fractures the material and thus becomes opaque. I don't understand why the damage cone would have a clean cylinder cut out of it like that. Explain?
Edit: So if you set the video speed to 0.25 and keep clicking 1:57 on the timeline you can see the point of impact balloon out in a donut shape while the tip of the bullet sort of bounces off. No explanation as to why this is but my best guess is the force propagates backward, causing the back of the bullet to break first. The path of least resistance for the wave from there is back down the outside of the bullet toward the front, the final pressure cone originate from the outside edge of the bullet impact site, not the full area.
